answers.explanation:
Structures appearing bright on the OCT are described to be hyper-reflective, while darker structures on OCT are described to be hypo-reflective. Whether a certain material is hyper-reflective or hypo-reflective depends on its ability to block light.

​Hyper-reflective on OCT (optically dense material, light blocking, less beam penetration): blood, drusen, cotton-wool spots, inflammatory cells, hard exudate.

​Hypo-reflective on OCT (optically clear, greater light penetration): fluid (vitreous cavity, intra-retinal/sub-retinal fluid).

Presence of subretinal hyper-reflective material (yellow arrow) in the sub-retinal space with preservation of the foveal contour and intact ellipsoid layer. There is no intra-retinal fluid. There is thinning of choroid (red bracket) as seen commonly in high myopia.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Based on the clinical presentation and the OCT, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
Myopic choroidal neovascular membrane (mCNV) is the second most common cause of CNV after AMD and occurs secondary to disruption of the integrity of the RPE/Bruch’s membrane complex. Upwards of 10 percent of eyes with degenerative myopia may develop CNV.

​In a study performed by Introni et al., it was found that outer retina characteristics (i.e. hyper-reflective lesion with fuzzy borders and absent/altered ISOS junction) are useful parameters in evaluating myopic CNVM activity. While mCNVM can have associated with sub-retinal or intra-retinal fluid, they are typically scarce or absent.

Reference:

1. https://www.aao.org/eyenet/article/diagnosis-treatment-of-cnv-in-myopic-macular-degen

2. Introini U, Casalino G, Querques G, Gimeno AT, Scotti F, Bandello F. Spectral-domain OCT in anti-VEGF treatment of myopic choroidal neovascularization. Eye. 2012 Jul;26(7):976-82.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: Which of the following can be used in the treatment of mCNVM?

answers.explanation: All the treatments listed above have been used in the management of mCNVM. Today, intravitreal anti-VEGF agents are considered first line in the management of mCNVM. Several major studies have looked at the safety and efficacy of anti-VEGF for this indication including the REPAIR, RADIANCE, and MYRROR studies, confirming the role of anti-VEGF agents for treating this condition.

title: Case 29
description: 35F presenting with decreased vision OS for 3 days
patientPresentation:
A 35 year old healthy female presented to the eye clinic with decreased vision in her left eye x 3 days. Her past ocular history was significant for myopia. She denied any recent ocular trauma.
​
On examination, vision was 20/20 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. There was no relative afferent pupillary defect and she had normal intraocular pressures. Slit lamp examination was normal. Dilated fundus examination demonstrated peri-papillary atrophy and tilted nerves in both eyes. An OCT macula was performed in both eyes, shown below:
